required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study to Test if Enzalutamide is Effective and Safe in Prostate Cancer Patients Who Have Never Had Hormone Therapy
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 2, Open-label, Single-arm, Efficacy and Safety Study of Enzalutamide (MDV3100) in Patients With Hormone-naïve Prostate Cancer

brief_summary.textblock: To evaluate the effect of enzalutamide on prostate specific antigen (PSA) level in men with prostate cancer.

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a Prostate-specific Antigen (PSA) Response at Week 25
primary_outcome.description: A PSA response was defined as a decline from Baseline in PSA level of 80% or greater. Blood samples for PSA were collected and analyzed at a central laboratory. Participants with an unknown or missing response or who discontinued prior to Week 25 for any reason were treated as non-responders.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Adverse Events
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first dose of study drug until 30 days after last dose. Adverse events with an onset date occurring within 2 years (i.e., before or on Day 730), as of the cut-off date of 28 December 2013, are reported.
secondary_outcome.description: Each adverse events (AE) was assessed by the investigator for causal relationship to the study drug; those deemed possibly or probably related to study drug are reported as drug regimen related AEs (DRRAEs). A serious adverse event (SAE) was defined as any untoward medical occurrence that at any dose: Resulted in death Was life-threatening Resulted in persistent or significant disability/incapacity Resulted in congenital anomaly or birth defect Required inpatient hospitalization or led to prolongation of hospitalization Other medically important events.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in PSA
Percent Change From Baseline in Sex Hormone-binding Globulin (SHBG)
Percent Change From Baseline in Androstenedione
Percent Change From Baseline in Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA)
Percent Change From Baseline in Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)
Percent Change From Baseline in Estradiol
Percent Change From Baseline in Follicle-stimulating Hormone (FSH)
Percent Change From Baseline in Luteinizing Hormone (LH)
Percent Change From Baseline in Prolactin
Percent Change From Baseline in Total Testosterone
Percent Change From Baseline in Free Testosterone
Plasma Concentration of Enzalutamide at Pre-dose (Ctrough)
Plasma Concentration of Enzalutamide Metabolite M2 at Pre-dose (Ctrough)
Percentage of Participants With a PSA Response at Weeks 49 and 97
secondary_outcome.description: A PSA response was defined as a decline from baseline in PSA level of 80% or greater. Blood samples for PSA were collected and analyzed at a central laboratory. Participants with an unknown or missing response or who discontinued prior to Week 49 or Week 97 for any reason were treated as non-responders.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a 90% or Greater Reduction From Baseline in PSA Level
secondary_outcome.description: Participants with unknown or missing PSA results at Week 25 or who discontinued prior to Week 25 were considered non-responders at Week 25. Participants with unknown or missing PSA results at Week 49 or Week 97 were considered non-responders.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With PSA ≤ 4 ng/ml
secondary_outcome.description: Participants with unknown or missing PSA results at Week 25 or who discontinued prior to Week 25 were considered non-responders at Week 25. Participants with unknown or missing PSA results at Week 49 or Week 97 were considered non-responders.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With PSA ≤ 0.1 ng/ml
secondary_outcome.description: Participants with unknown or missing PSA results at Week 25 or who discontinued prior to Week 25 were considered non-responders at Week 25. Participants with unknown or missing PSA results at Week 49 or Week 97 were considered non-responders.

secondary_outcome.measure: Maximum Decline From Baseline in PSA
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to Week 25 and from Baseline up to the data cut-off date of 28 December 2013; median duration of treatment was 754.0 days (range of 52-929)
secondary_outcome.description: The maximum decline from Baseline in PSA was calculated as the largest reduction from Baseline in PSA level that occurred at any point after treatment start up to Week 25 and up to and including the assessment made at the safety follow-up visit, divided by the PSA Baseline value and multiplied by 100, i.e., the maximum percent change from baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to PSA Response
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first dose until the data cut-off date of 28 December 2013; median duration of treatment was 754.0 days (range of 52-929 days)
secondary_outcome.description: Time to PSA response (PSA decline ≥ 80% from Baseline) is defined as the time interval from the first study drug dose to the first date a decline from Baseline in PSA level of 80% or greater was recorded. Time to response was estimated using the Kaplan-Meier method.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to PSA Decline ≥ 90%
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first dose until the data cut-off date of 28 December 2013; median duration of treatment was 754.0 days (range of 52-929 days)
secondary_outcome.description: Time to PSA decline ≥ 90% is defined as the time interval from the first study drug dose to the first date a decline from Baseline in PSA level of 90% or greater was recorded. Time to PSA decline ≥ 90% was estimated using the Kaplan-Meier method.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to PSA ≤ 4 ng/ml
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first dose until the data cut-off date of 28 December 2013; median duration of treatment was 754.0 days (range of 52-929 days).
secondary_outcome.description: Time to PSA ≤ 4 ng/ml is defined as the time interval from the first study drug dose to the first date a decline in PSA to a result of 4 ng/ml or below was recorded. Time to PSA ≤ 4 ng/ml was estimated using the Kaplan-Meier method.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to PSA ≤ 0.1 ng/ml
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first dose until the data cut-off date of 28 December 2013; median duration of treatment was 754.0 days (range of 52-929 days).
secondary_outcome.description: Time to PSA ≤ 0.1 ng/ml is defined as the time interval from the first study drug dose to the first date a decline in PSA to a result of 0.1 ng/ml or below was recorded. Time to PSA ≤ 0.1 ng/ml was estimated using the Kaplan-Meier method.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to PSA Progression
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first dose until the data cut-off date of 28 December 2013; median duration of treatment was 754.0 days (range of 52-929 days).
secondary_outcome.description: Time to PSA progression is defined as the time interval from the first study drug dose to the first date of PSA progression. PSA progression is defined as a ≥ 25% increase in PSA with an absolute increase of ≥ 2 ng/mL above the nadir unless the PSA next measurement(s), if available, does not confirm the PSA progression.

secondary_outcome.measure: PSA Doubling Time
secondary_outcome.description: PSA doubling time was to be calculated from the slope estimated from a linear regression of the natural log of PSA fitted on time, if the slope was positive. Since the slope was negative for all participants, PSA doubling time could not be calculated.

arm_group.description: Participants received oral enzalutamide at 160 mg once daily for 24 weeks. Participants who had clinical benefit at Week 25 could continue to receive enzalutamide until disease progression, objective or clinical, or occurrence of an unacceptable toxicity, at the discretion of the investigator.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Histologically confirmed prostate cancer (all stages) for whom androgen deprivation therapy is indicated (except when indicated in a neoadjuvant/adjuvant therapy)
- Asymptomatic from prostate cancer
- Non-castrate level of testosterone (≥ 8 nmol/L (230 ng/dL)) at screening
- PSA ≥ 2 ng/mL at screening
Exclusion Criteria:
Has previously or is currently receiving:
- Hormonal therapy with intent to treat prostate cancer
- Systemic glucocorticoids
- Chemotherapy with the intent to treat prostate cancer
- Opiate analgesics for pain from prostate cancer
- Radiation therapy for treatment of the primary tumor or metastases
- Has history of known or suspected brain or skull metastases or leptomeningeal disease
- Has history of seizure including febrile seizure or any condition that may predispose to seizure or history of loss of consciousness or transient ischemic attack
- Clinically significant cardiovascular disease

link.description: Link to results on Astellas Clinical Study Results website

participant_flow.recruitment_details: This study is ongoing, data are reported as of the 2 year cut-off date of 28 December 2013.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants received oral enzalutamide at 160 mg once daily for 24 weeks. Participants who had clinical benefit at Week 25 could continue to receive enzalutamide until disease progression, objective or clinical, or occurrence of an unacceptable toxicity, at the discretion of the investigator.

participants_list.participants: Participants who discontinued treatment and completed the 30-day follow-up visit

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants received oral enzalutamide at 160 mg once daily for 24 weeks. Participants who had clinical benefit at Week 25 could continue to receive enzalutamide until disease progression, objective or clinical, or occurrence of an unacceptable toxicity, at the discretion of the investigator.

measure.title: Age
Sex: Female, Male
Body Mass Index (BMI)
Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA)
Duration of prostate cancer
Total Gleason Score at Initial Diagnosis
measure.description: A system of grading prostate cancer tissue based on how it looks under a microscope. Gleason scores range from 2 to 10 and indicate how likely it is that a tumor will spread. A low Gleason score means the cancer tissue is similar to normal prostate tissue and the tumor is less likely to spread; a high Gleason score means the cancer tissue is very different from normal and the tumor is more likely to spread.

measure.title: Clinical Tumor Stage (T) at Initial Diagnosis

class.title: TX: Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0: No evidence of primary tumor
T1: Tumor neither palpable or visible by imaging
T2: Tumor confined within the prostate
T3: Tumor extends through the prostatic capsule
T4: Tumor is fixed or invades adjacent structures

measure.title: Clinical Lymph Node Stage (N) at Initial Diagnosis

class.title: NX: Regional lymph nodes were not assessed
N0: No regional lymph node metastasis
N1: Metastasis in regional lymph node(s)

measure.title: Distant Metastasis (M) at Initial Diagnosis

class.title: MX: Distant metastasis could not be assessed

measure.title: Participants with Metastases at Study Entry
Number of Metastatic Lesions by Bone Scan
Previous Interventions
measure.description: Participants may have received more than one intervention

measure.population: Safety Analysis Set

outcome.title: Time to PSA Progression
outcome.description: Time to PSA progression is defined as the time interval from the first study drug dose to the first date of PSA progression. PSA progression is defined as a ≥ 25% increase in PSA with an absolute increase of ≥ 2 ng/mL above the nadir unless the PSA next measurement(s), if available, does not confirm the PSA progression.
outcome.time_frame: From first dose until the data cut-off date of 28 December 2013; median duration of treatment was 754.0 days (range of 52-929 days).
outcome.population: Safety Analysis Set

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants received oral enzalutamide at 160 mg once daily for 24 weeks. Participants who had clinical benefit at Week 25 could continue to receive enzalutamide until disease progression, objective or clinical, or occurrence of an unacceptable toxicity, at the discretion of the investigator.

measure.title: Time to PSA Progression
measure.description: Time to PSA progression is defined as the time interval from the first study drug dose to the first date of PSA progression. PSA progression is defined as a ≥ 25% increase in PSA with an absolute increase of ≥ 2 ng/mL above the nadir unless the PSA next measurement(s), if available, does not confirm the PSA progression.
measure.population: Safety Analysis Set

measurement_list.measurement: Could not be estimated due to the low number of events

outcome.title: PSA Doubling Time
outcome.description: PSA doubling time was to be calculated from the slope estimated from a linear regression of the natural log of PSA fitted on time, if the slope was positive. Since the slope was negative for all participants, PSA doubling time could not be calculated.
outcome.population: Safety Analysis Set with a positive PSA versus time slope

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants received oral enzalutamide at 160 mg once daily for 24 weeks. Participants who had clinical benefit at Week 25 could continue to receive enzalutamide until disease progression, objective or clinical, or occurrence of an unacceptable toxicity, at the discretion of the investigator.

measure.title: PSA Doubling Time
measure.description: PSA doubling time was to be calculated from the slope estimated from a linear regression of the natural log of PSA fitted on time, if the slope was positive. Since the slope was negative for all participants, PSA doubling time could not be calculated.
measure.population: Safety Analysis Set with a positive PSA versus time slope

reported_events.time_frame: From first dose of study drug until 30 days after last dose. Adverse events with an onset date occurring within 2 years (i.e., before or on Day 730), as of the cut-off date of 28 December 2013, are reported.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants received oral enzalutamide at 160 mg once daily for 24 weeks. Participants who had clinical benefit at week 25 could continue to receive enzalutamide until disease progression, objective or clinical, or occurrence of an unacceptable toxicity, at the discretion of the investigator.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Institute and/or Principal Investigator may publish trial data generated at their specific study site. Sponsor must receive a site’s manuscript at least 90 days prior to publication for review and comment.
